title: Jeff W. Mathis III
text:
Jeff W. Mathis III (December 5, 1955 - June 3, 2016) was a career officer in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a>. A longtime member of the <a href="Army%20National%20Guard">Army National Guard</a>, Mathis attained the rank of <a href="Major%20general%20%28United%20States%29">major general</a> before retiring in 2014. A veteran of overseas deployment to <a href="Africa">Africa</a> during the <a href="War%20on%20terror">Global War on Terrorism</a>, he was most notable for high profile command assignments including <a href="Joint%20Task%20Force%20%E2%80%93%20Civil%20Support">Joint Task Force – Civil Support</a> (2012-2014) and <a href="I%20Corps%20%28United%20States%29">I Corps</a> (2009-2010).
Early life.
Jeff Walter Mathis was born in <a href="Oklahoma%20City%2C%20Oklahoma">Oklahoma City, Oklahoma</a> on December 5, 1955, the son of Jeff Hudson Mathis II and Georgia Virginia “Ginny” Wells. He was raised in <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a> and South America while his father served with the <a href="United%20States%20Air%20Force">United States Air Force</a>, and graduated from <a href="John%20Marshall%20High%20School%20%28Leon%20Valley%2C%20Texas%29">John Marshall High School</a> in <a href="Leon%20Valley%2C%20Texas">Leon Valley, Texas</a> in 1974. In 1975, Mathis enlisted in the United States Army as a communications specialist, and during his time as an enlisted soldier he attained the rank of <a href="Sergeant%23United%20States">sergeant</a> and completed the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Special%20Forces">Special Forces Qualification Course</a>. In 1981, he earned a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> degree in education from Florida Bible College in <a href="Hollywood%2C%20Florida">Hollywood, Florida</a>.
Start of career.
Mathis was a member of the <a href="Florida%20Army%20National%20Guard">Florida Army National Guard</a> when he completed <a href="Officer%20Candidate%20School%20%28United%20States%20Army%29">Officer Candidate School</a> and received his commission as a <a href="Second%20lieutenant%23United%20States">second lieutenant</a> of <a href="Infantry%20Branch%20%28United%20States%29">Infantry</a>. His initial assignments included platoon leader, Company A, 1st Battalion, <a href="124th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">124th Infantry Regiment</a> (July 1981-January 1983) and assistant plans, operations, and training officer (S-3) of 1st Battalion, <a href="265th%20Air%20Defense%20Artillery%20Regiment">265th Air Defense Artillery Regiment</a> (February 1983-March 1985). Mathis was promoted to <a href="First%20lieutenant%23U.S.%20Army%2C%20U.S.%20Marine%20Corps%2C%20U.S.%20Air%20Force%2C%20and%20U.S.%20Space%20Force">first lieutenant</a> in July 1984.
From March to October 1985, Mathis commanded Headquarters Battery, 1st Battalion, 265th Air Defense Artillery. He then served as human resources staff officer (S-1) for 3rd Battalion, <a href="20th%20Special%20Forces%20Group">20th Special Forces Group</a> (October 1985-August 1987). He was promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28United%20States%20O-3%29">captain</a> in June 1986.
Mathis served as future plans officer (S-5) for 3rd Battalion, 20th Special Forces Group from August 1987 to April 1988. From April 1988 to February 1989 he was S-1 for the <a href="164th%20Air%20Defense%20Artillery%20Brigade%20%28United%20States%29">164th Air Defense Artillery Brigade</a>. In 1989, Mathis completed a <a href="Master%20of%20Science">Master of Science</a> degree in management at <a href="Troy%20State%20University">Troy State University</a>. In February 1989, Mathis joined the <a href="New%20York%20Army%20National%20Guard">New York Army National Guard</a> and was assigned as assistant human resources officer (G-1) on the staff of the <a href="42nd%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">42nd Infantry Division</a>. He served in this position until November 1989, then was assigned as personnel officer at Detachment 1, Headquarters, New York State Area Command. He was promoted to <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> in April 1991, and remained in this position until December.
Continued career.
From December 1991 to December 1992, Mathis served as assistant chief of staff for personnel at Detachment 1, Headquarters, New York State Area Command. In December 1992, he was assigned as chief of the training section for Operations Readiness Evaluation Team 1, <a href="Sixth%20United%20States%20Army">Sixth United States Army</a> at the <a href="Presidio%20of%20San%20Francisco">Presidio of San Francisco</a>, California, where he remained until September 1993. From October 1993 to May 1994, he was assigned as operations officer and deputy chief of staff for operations on the Sixth Army staff. Mathis served as S-3 of 3rd Battalion (Officer Candidate School), <a href="11th%20Infantry%20Regiment%20%28United%20States%29">11th Infantry Regiment</a> at <a href="Fort%20Benning">Fort Benning</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Georgia</a> from May 1994 to May 1995.
Mathis attended the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Command%20and%20General%20Staff%20College">United States Army Command and General Staff College</a> at <a href="Fort%20Leavenworth">Fort Leavenworth</a>, <a href="Kansas">Kansas</a> from July to December 1995. After graduating, he was assigned as deputy director and Army National Guard advisor at the Reserve Component Directorate of the <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy%20Special%20Warfare%20Center%20and%20School">John F. Kennedy Special Warfare Center and School</a>, where he served until July 1996. From August 1996 to April 1998, Mathis was assigned as director of program integration and Army National Guard Advisor for the Army Special Operations Forces XXI Program Integration Office. From April 1998 to June 1999 he attended the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20War%20College">United States Army War College</a> in <a href="Carlisle%2C%20Pennsylvania">Carlisle, Pennsylvania</a>. After graduating, Mathis was assigned as a strategic planner for the director's staff group at the headquarters of the <a href="Army%20National%20Guard">Army National Guard</a> in <a href="Arlington%2C%20Virginia">Arlington, Virginia</a>, where he served from June 1999 to June 2000. From June 2000 to June 2001, Mathis was director of Program Oversight in the Office of the Deputy <a href="Assistant%20Secretary%20of%20Defense%20for%20Manpower%20and%20Reserve%20Affairs">Assistant Secretary of Defense for Manpower and Reserve Affairs</a>. He was promoted to <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a> in October 2000.
From June 2001 to June 2003, Mathis served as chief of the Homeland Defense Division at the <a href="National%20Guard%20Bureau">National Guard Bureau</a>. From July 2003 to September 2003 he commanded Special Operations Detachment - Pacific, a unit of the <a href="Washington%20Army%20National%20Guard">Washington Army National Guard</a>. Mathis served as deputy commander and chief of staff for <a href="Combined%20Joint%20Task%20Force%20%E2%80%93%20Horn%20of%20Africa">Combined Joint Task Force – Horn of Africa</a> in <a href="Djibouti">Djibouti</a> from October 2003 to June 2004. From July 2004 to July 2006, Mathis commanded the Washington National Guard's Special Operations Detachment – Pacific and Joint Task Force – Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear and Explosive Emergency Response. In 2006, he completed the Joint Task Force Commander's Course at <a href="United%20States%20Northern%20Command">United States Northern Command</a>. Mathis served as director of the Joint Staff for the Washington National Guard from August 2006 to June 2008, and was promoted to <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> in May 2007.
Career as general officer.
From June 2008 to March 2009, Mathis served as deputy commander (rear detachment) for <a href="I%20Corps%20%28United%20States%29">I Corps</a> at <a href="Joint%20Base%20Lewis%E2%80%93McChord">Joint Base Lewis–McChord</a>, Washington. In 2008, he completed the Senior Commander's Course at <a href="Fort%20Belvoir">Fort Belvoir</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a> and the Army Strategic Leadership Development Program - Intermediate at the <a href="University%20of%20North%20Carolina%20at%20Chapel%20Hill">University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill</a>. In 2009, Mathis graduated from the Senior Executive Seminar at the <a href="George%20C.%20Marshall%20European%20Center%20for%20Security%20Studies">George C. Marshall European Center for Security Studies</a> in <a href="Garmisch-Partenkirchen">Garmisch-Partenkirchen</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. He served as commander of I Corps from March 2009 to April 2010. From April to July 2010, he again served as I Corps' deputy commander. Mathis served as deputy director of antiterrorism and homeland defense (J-34) on the staff of the <a href="Joint%20Chiefs%20of%20Staff">Joint Chiefs of Staff</a> from July 2010 to July 2012. In 2010, Mathis completed the Army Senior Leadership Development Program - Advanced. In January 2011, Mathis was promoted to major general, and later that year he graduated from the <a href="National%20Defense%20University">National Defense University</a>'s CAPSTONE program at <a href="Fort%20Lesley%20J.%20McNair">Fort Lesley J. McNair</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> In July 2012, Mathis was assigned to command <a href="Joint%20Task%20Force%20%E2%80%93%20Civil%20Support">Joint Task Force – Civil Support</a> at <a href="Fort%20Eustis">Fort Eustis</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a> and he remained in this position until retiring in July 2014.

Later career.
After retiring from the military, Mathis resided in <a href="Suffolk%2C%20Virginia">Suffolk, Virginia</a> and was managing director of Variable Solutions International, a consulting business that provided emergency management and homeland security advice and guidance to government and corporate clients. He also served on the board of directors for <a href="Christopher%20Newport%20University">Christopher Newport University</a>'s Center for American Studies and the advisory board for <a href="Peninsula%20Catholic%20High%20School">Peninsula Catholic High School</a> in <a href="Newport%20News%2C%20Virginia">Newport News, Virginia</a>. In addition, Mathis was a guest lecturer at the Army War College, National Defense University, and <a href="George%20Washington%20University">George Washington University</a>.
Mathis died at <a href="Naval%20Medical%20Center%20Portsmouth">Naval Medical Center Portsmouth</a> in <a href="Portsmouth%2C%20Virginia">Portsmouth, Virginia</a> on June 3, 2016. He was buried at Arlington National Cemetery.
Family.
In 1991, Mathis married Christine Pendill. They were the parents of two children, Declan Mathis and Cecily Mathis.
